Translated by the Wu Dynasty Kangju monk Kang Sengkai
Chapter 1: The Perfection of Generosity, with ten sub-chapters
Thus have I heard:
Once, the Buddha was at Vulture Peak in the country of RÄjagá¹›ha.
At that time, he was sitting with five hundred Å›rÄvakas and one thousand bodhisattvas.
Among them, there was a bodhisattva named Aniruddha. When the Buddha expounded the scriptures, he always listened with a tranquil mind, silent and without thought, his mind focused on the scriptures.
The Honored One knew this and spoke for him, saying:
The six perfections of the bodhisattva are difficult to attain and lead to lofty conduct, quickly attaining Buddhahood.
What are the six?
First, generosity; second, upholding precepts; third, patience; fourth, diligence; fifth, meditation; sixth, the lofty conduct of the perfection of wisdom.
What is the perfection of generosity?

Nurturing people and things with kindness, having compassion for the many deviant paths, joyfully cultivating the perfections, and saving sentient beings, surpassing heaven and earth, the vastness of its moisture like a river or sea.

Giving to sentient beings, the hungry eat it, the thirsty drink it, the cold are clothed, the hot are cooled, the sick are given medicine, carriages, horses, boats, precious treasures, famous and precious things, wives, children, and the country - if asked for, they are given.
Like Prince SudÄna, giving to the poor and needy, nurturing them like his own children, though the king, his father, banished him, he felt pity and did not resent it.
In the past, the Bodhisattva, his mind penetrating the truth, saw that the world is impermanent, and that glorious life is difficult to preserve. He gave away all his wealth in charity.

Indra, seeing the Bodhisattva's kindness in nurturing the multitude of beings and giving to the masses, his merits towering, his virtues weighty in the ten directions, feared he would lose his own position, and so transformed into a hell, appearing before him, saying:
'By giving alms to the masses, when one's life ends, one's soul enters the great mountain hells, where one is burned and cooked with myriad poisons.
For giving, one receives harm. Is this your kindness?'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'How could there be one who enters the great mountain hells due to the virtue of giving?'
The Buddha said:
'If you do not believe, you can ask the guilty ones.
' The Bodhisattva asked:
'For what reason are you in the hells?'
The criminal said:
'In my past life, I gave alms to the poor in an empty house, and rescued many from misfortune. Now I receive heavy punishment and am in the great mountain hells.'
The Bodhisattva asked:
'You received misfortune from kindness. What about the recipient of the alms?'
The Buddha said:
'The recipient of the kindness ascended to heaven upon the end of his life.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'I rescue and help only for the sake of sentient beings;
If it is as you say, it is truly my wish.'
I will certainly take on the suffering for them.
Risking oneself to save others is the highest aspiration of a bodhisattva.'
The Buddha said:
'What aspirations do you have? You still pursue this lofty practice?'
He replied:
'I wish to seek Buddhahood, to deliver sentient beings, and enable them to attain nirvana and no longer undergo birth and death.'
When the Buddha heard his noble intention, he then bowed his head and said:
'There is truly no giving or compassionately saving sentient beings, far from blessings and suffering misfortune to enter the prison of Mount Tai.
Fearing that your virtue will shake the heavens and earth and rob me of my position, I therefore showed you the hells to confuse your aspirations.
Foolishly deceiving the sages, I will repent my grave faults.'
Having repented, he bowed his head and withdrew.
The bodhisattva's practice of giving with boundless compassion is like this.

2. The Past Life of King SavardhÄna (2) In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great king named SavardhÄna. He gave to sentient beings whatever they requested, and had compassion and pity for those in distress.
Indra, seeing the king's benevolent virtue pervading the ten directions, said to the celestial spirits and dragons,
'The exalted position of Indra is never held by ordinary people. One who is fully virtuous, highly compassionate, and has abundant blessings will become Indra upon the end of their life.'
Fearing that the king would take his position, he wanted to test him to discern the true from the false.
Indra ordered a border king,
'That human king now has abundant blessings and benevolence, and I fear he will seek to take my position as Indra.
You transform into a dove, quickly go to the king, pretend to be terrified, and seek refuge from the king.
That king is kind and benevolent, he will surely accept you.
I will follow you later and ask the king for you.'
The king will certainly not return it, and will instead buy meat to replace it.
I will deceive him and not stop, but the king's intention is pure and true, and he will not go back on his word. He will surely cut off his own flesh to replace the weight.
If the meat on the scale follows and becomes heavier, and the meat is exhausted, his body will hurt and he will surely regret it.
If his mind has regret, his intention will not be accomplished.'
The Buddha then transformed into a hawk, and the king transformed into a dove.
The dove quickly flew to the king's feet and said in fear:
'Great king, have mercy on me!
My life is coming to an end!
' The king said:
'Do not fear, do not fear!
I will save you now.'
The hawk soon arrived and said to the king:
'My dove has come here. The dove is my food. I wish the king would return it to me.' The king said:
'The dove came to entrust its life to me. It has already taken refuge in me. I keep my word and will not go back on it from beginning to end.'
If you can get the meat, I will be satisfied with it, and I will give you a hundred times more.
The hawk said:
I only want the dove, I do not need other meat. I hope the king will be kind to me.
Why do you take away my food?
The king said:
I have already accepted their surrender, and my faith is heavy as the heavens and the earth. With what mind would I go against it?
What can I use to make you let the dove go and leave happily?
The hawk said:
If the king's kindness and compassion must save all beings, cut off the king's flesh to weigh it and make it equal to the dove. I will happily accept it.
The king said:
Excellent!
He then cut off his thigh meat and weighed it to make it equal to the dove's weight;
The dove was heavier than itself. He cut like this, and all the flesh on his body was exhausted, but it was still not equal in weight. The pain of the wounds on his body was immeasurable.
The king, with a mind of compassionate forbearance, wished for the dove to live, and again ordered his ministers:
Quickly kill me, and weigh the marrow to make it equal to the dove's weight.

I uphold the Buddhas' teachings and receive the weighty precepts of true enlightenment, to save sentient beings from danger and distress. Although there are various evil disturbances, they are like a gentle breeze, how can they move Mount Tai?'
'King Gyokushin, cherishing the Way without wavering, his benevolence and kindness unmatched, each returned to their original bodies.
Shakra and the border king bowed to the ground and said:
'Great King!
What aspirations do you have, to suffer such torment?'
The human king said:

'I do not aspire to the position of Shakra, the Lord of the Devas, or to be a flying emperor. I see sentient beings drowning in blindness and darkness, not seeing the Three Treasures, not hearing the Buddha's teachings, indulging their minds in evil and harmful actions, throwing themselves into the AvÄ«ci Hell.
Seeing this foolishness and confusion, I feel deeply saddened.
I vow to seek Buddhahood, to save sentient beings from their difficulties and distress, and to enable them to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.'
Shakra was startled and said:
'Foolishly, I thought the Great King wanted to take my position, so I disturbed him.
What instructions do you have for me?
The king said:
Make my body's wounds heal and return to normal, and make my aspiration for giving and saving others surpass the present.

The Heavenly Emperor then dispatched a heavenly doctor and divine medicine, and the body's wounds healed and its appearance and strength surpassed before, and the body's wounds instantly completely healed.
Åšakra then bowed, circumambulated the king three times, and joyfully left.
From then on, his giving surpassed before.
The bodhisattva's practice of giving with compassion and kindness is like this.

[The Story of the Poor Man's Past Life] (3) In the past, the bodhisattva was extremely poor and destitute. He went to another country with some merchants. The group all had the aspiration to have faith in the Buddha and give to the poor to save sentient beings.
The people all said:
'Everyone is compassionate and kind, what will you give?'
He replied:
'This body is a borrowed thing, and none will abandon it. I see sea fish, large and small, swallowing each other, and my heart is deeply moved.
I shall use my body to replace the smaller one, and let it live for a while.'
He then threw himself into the sea.
The great fish in the sea was satisfied, and the smaller one was saved.
His spirit transformed into the king of a large fish, with a body of several li.
On the seashore there was a country, which was suffering from drought. The people were starving and cannibalistic.
The fish shed tears and said:
'The suffering of sentient beings is painful!
My body has several li of flesh, which can provide for the people's lack for several months.'
He then threw himself onto the shore of the country. The whole country ate it to save their lives. They carried the flesh for several months and the fish was still alive.
The celestial spirits descended and said:ğŸ”½'Your endurance of suffering is unbearable!
Why don't you let go of your life and leave this pain?'
The fish said:
I will take my own life, let my spirit depart, and my body rot. The people will later face famine and will probably eat each other again. I cannot bear to witness this.
His heart was moved by this, and the heavens said:
The compassion of a bodhisattva is difficult to match.
The heavens, moved by his heart, said:
If you definitely attain Buddhahood, you will save my sentient beings.
Someone with an ax cut off its head, and the fish died at that time.
Its spirit immediately became the king's crown prince.
Born with the wisdom of a superior sage, his four kinds of kindness and vast compassion moistened and equaled the two polarities.
He pitied the people's poverty and hardship, and choked with sobs when speaking of it.
However, the country was still suffering from drought. He calmed his mind, rectified himself, withdrew his meals, and stopped presenting offerings. He bowed his head and repented, saying:
The people's unwholesomeness is my fault. I wish to lose my life and bestow rain and dew on the people.
Day after day, he grieved like a filial son who has lost his sage father.
With sincere heart and far-reaching understanding, five hundred Buddhas each came to his country.
The king, hearing this, was delighted as if he had no body, and welcomed them with his head bowed, inviting them to return to the main hall.
The empress and prince were all reverent, offering the finest Dharma robes and providing for their needs. They threw themselves on the ground, bowed their heads, and wept, saying:
'My defiled conduct is turbid, not in accord with the teachings of the Three Jewels and the Four Kindnesses. I have cruelly oppressed the people, and my crimes deserve to be punished.
The suffering has spread to the lowly, with drought lasting for years. The people are starving and resentful, hurting my feelings.
I wish to remove the people's disasters and take the blame upon myself.'
The various Buddhas said:
'You are a benevolent ruler, compassionate and kind, your virtue equal to that of Åšakra. The Buddhas know all.
Now I bestow blessings upon you, do not be distressed.
Swiftly order the people to plant grain.

The king then did as he was told, and the men and women went to work. No household did not engage in cultivation. The rice transformed into gourds. The agricultural ministers reported this to the king.
The king said:
Wait until they are ripe.
The gourd fruits covered the country, all containing rice grains. The middle could hold several hu. Its taste was fragrant, and the fragrance was smelled throughout the country.
The entire country rejoiced and praised the king's virtue.
The neighboring countries all became vassals. The common people gathered like clouds, and the borders of the country expanded day by day.
The entire country upheld the precepts and took refuge in the Three Jewels. After the king, ministers, and people passed away, they were all reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha said:
The poor man at that time was me.
For many kalpas, I was kind and generous, saving sentient beings. My merits were not in vain. I have now attained Buddhahood, called the Heaven of Heavens, the hero of the three realms.
The bodhisattva's kindness and generosity are inexhaustible. Practicing giving like this.
In the past, when the Bodhisattva was a deer, he always lived in the mountains and forests, single-mindedly contemplating the Way and not committing any evil.

He ate fruits and drank water, not storing even a little bit, and had loving thoughts for sentient beings who were foolish and suffering. Whenever he saw danger and hardship, he would risk his life to save them.
While walking in search of fruits and vegetables, he encountered a lactating tigress.
After the tigress had finished nursing, she was tired and hungry, lacking food, and her mind was confused by hunger. She wanted to return to eat her cubs.

The Bodhisattva saw this and felt deeply saddened. He pitifully thought of sentient beings living in the world with immeasurable suffering, and the pain of mother and child devouring each other was difficult to describe. He choked back tears.
He turned his body and looked around in all directions, searching for something to feed the tiger and save the cubs' lives.
He did not see anything at all. He thought to himself:
'Tigers are carnivorous animals.'
He deeply pondered:
'I have set my mind on learning the Way, only to save sentient beings who are drowning in heavy suffering, to deliver them from misfortune and bring them eternal peace.
After I die of old age, my body will be abandoned anyway, it is better to save the multitude and accomplish virtue with kindness and generosity.'
So he threw himself into the tiger's mouth with his head.
When giving his head, he wanted to die quickly and did not feel the pain.
The tiger and her cubs were all saved.
The Buddhas praised his virtue, the supreme sages equaled his merit, and the heavenly dragons, good spirits, and those with the aspiration for the Way, none were not moved.
Some made progress and attained the stages of stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, arhat, pratyekabuddha, or gave rise to the intention for supreme, perfect enlightenment.

With this fierce resolve, he surpassed the bodhisattvas nine kalpas before, vowing to be the teacher of gods and humans in the five turbidities, to deliver the rebellious and evil and make them conform to the Way.
This is how a bodhisattva practices giving with kindness and generosity to the utmost.

In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great king of a country named Gana, with the title of Paravata. He was wise within and benevolent without, with a peaceful and upright countenance. The people followed his teachings, the prison was without prisoners, and the poor and destitute were allowed to seek what they needed. His kindness and compassion were like the grace of Indra.
The ascetics of other countries, who admired the king's benevolence and granting of people's wishes, were jealous and slandered the truth with falsehood. They went to the palace gate and said:
'We have heard that the wise king saves the people from poverty and hardship, just as the heavens universally cover with moisture.'
He told the guards:
'Can you hear this?'
The close ministers reported it to the king, and the king immediately appeared.
The ascetic appeared and said:
'The wise king's benevolent grace extends to the four countries. Those with consciousness all praise it. I dare to hold my wish and wish to report it to the king.' The king said:
'Very good!'
The ascetic said:ğŸ”½The king said:
'The Heavenly King still gives, seeking is not in vain.
It is timely to use human heads for the matter, I wish to beg the king's head to fulfill my hope.'
The king said:
'What is good about my head that you want it?
I have many treasures, I will give them to you as a gift.'
The mind of the deceased did not accept it, and again had craftsmen make hundreds of jeweled heads with the seven treasures, and gave them to the mind of the deceased.
The mind of the deceased said:
'I only want the king's head.'
The king, who had never gone against people, immediately went down from the hall and wrapped his hair around a tree, saying:
'I give my head to you.'

The mind of the deceased drew his sword and quickly stepped forward. The tree spirit saw him and was angry at his lack of virtue. He slapped his cheek with his hand, and his body immediately twisted, his face turned around, and the sword in his hand fell.
The king recovered, and the ministers and people praised his longevity. Sorrow and joy mixed together, and the gods praised his virtue. It can be said to be inner giving!

The four heavenly kings will protect them, and all poisons will be dispelled. The realm will be free from illness, the five grains will ripen well, prisons will be torn down, and the ruler and people will be delighted.
The Buddha told the monks:
The king of the Dryad country at that time was none other than myself.
The one with the mind of passing away was Devadatta.
The bodhisattva, out of kindness and generosity, practices giving like this.

[The Birth Story of the King] (6) In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great king. He ruled the people with kindness, and he put himself in the shoes of others. Month after month, he went around to the poor, rescuing widows and orphans, and providing medicine and porridge for the sick.
Whenever he went out on a tour of inspection, he would order the rear carriage to be fully loaded with various treasures, clothes, medicine, and other necessities. He would bury those who died.
Whenever he saw poor people, he would blame himself, thinking:
'If the ruler is poor, the people will be impoverished.
If the ruler is rich, the people's homes will be well-stocked.
Now that the people are poor, I am poor.'
The king's kindness was like this, and his fame spread in the ten directions.
The second Indra sat there, feeling hot, and his mind became fearful, thinking:
'His virtue is lofty and majestic, he will surely take away my position.
My plan to destroy his resolve is complete!'

'I was born in an ordinary family with little merit from past lives. I admire noble and prosperous [positions] and wish to beg for this country.'
The king said:
'Very good!'
He immediately left with his wife and children in a light carriage.
The Heavenly Emperor transformed again into a brahman and begged the king for his carriage;
He gave him the carriage and horse.
He continued on his way with his wife and children and stopped to rest by a mountain.

There were five men of the Way who were friends with the king. They remembered the king's virtue and looked up at his lodging. They saw that he had lost his country. They calmed their minds and rested in meditation, seeing that the Heavenly Emperor, out of greed and jealousy, had taken away the king's country, causing him to be exhausted and weary.
The men of the Way suddenly appeared before the king with their spiritual powers and said:
'What do you wish to seek, to toil your mind like this?'
He said:
'What I aspire to, you know well.'
The men of the Way then transformed into a one-wheeled carriage and sent the king back. They parted ways at dawn.
The god transformed into a brahman again and begged for the carriage, so he gave it to him again.
As he proceeded further, not yet reaching the country, several tens of li away, the god again transformed into the previous brahman and came to ask for the silver coins.
The king said:
I have given the country to others, and I have forgotten about your coins.
The brahman said:
In three days, you must return my coins.
The king then mortgaged his wife to one family, and obtained one thousand silver coins to return to the brahman.

His wife served in the family where she was mortgaged. The daughter bathed and took off her body's pearls and various treasures to hang on a rack. The god transformed into a hawk and snatched the treasures from the clothes.
The daughter said:
A maid stole!
They recorded it and put her in prison.
Her son was lying together with the son of the family where he was mortgaged. The god went at night and killed the son of the family where he was mortgaged.

The dead family took the son and put him in prison. The mother and son were both imprisoned. Hungry and emaciated, they called out for help, but no one came to their rescue. They lamented all day long, and their crimes were confirmed, so they were abandoned in the marketplace.
The king, having obtained a thousand silver coins, went to redeem his wife and son. As he passed through the market, he recalled the Buddhas of the ten directions and repented his faults, saying:
'My evil from past lives has brought me to this!
' He calmed his mind and entered meditation, and through the clarity of his spiritual powers, he saw what the gods had done.
A voice in the sky said:
'Why don't you quickly kill them?'
The king said:

'I have heard that Shakra universally delivers sentient beings, with a heart of utmost compassion, nurturing more than a kind mother. No creature does not receive his blessings. Have you no evil karma to attain the position of Shakra?'
Shakra, harboring heavy poison, evil fully ripened, was born into Mount Tai;
The gods, humans, dragons, and ghosts all praised it as good.
The king of the land was the one who committed the crime of killing the king's wife and son.
When the two kings met, they immediately asked about the reason. When they fully explained the cause, none in the country, from the great to the small, did not shed tears.
The king of the land divided the country and ruled it;
The people of the former country followed the king's whereabouts and welcomed him throughout the land.
The rulers and people of the two countries, one sorrowful and one joyful.
At that time, the king was me.
The wife was Gautami.
The son was Rahula.
The Heavenly Emperor was Devadatta.
The mountain hermit was Shariputra.
The king of that country was Maitreya.
The Bodhisattva's practice of giving with compassion and wisdom is like this.
[The Birth Story of the King] (7) Long ago, the Bodhisattva was a great king who governed the people with justice, his mind impartial. However, he did not go out for excursions.
The prime minister said to him:
'Please go out on an excursion.' The king said:
'Very good!'
The next day, he went out.
The people were delighted and all got what they wanted. Seeing the wealthy families in the country with exquisite houses, roofed with gold and silver, and their garments shining on the road, he said:
'My country is prosperous!'
His heart was very joyful.
Returning to the palace, he thought of it and said:
'What benefit do these householders bring to the country?'
He ordered the recording of their wealth as military reserves.
There was a householder whose private wealth amounted to three million, who presented a petition to the king.
The king angrily said:
'How dare you deceive me to my face?'
He replied:
'Since I was young, I have been managing my livelihood. All my private wealth in the house belongs to the five families and is not mine.'
He said:
'What do you call private wealth?'
He replied:

'Thinking of the Buddha's teachings in the mind, proclaiming the Buddha's teachings with the mouth, and practicing the Buddha's deeds with the body, I have given up the five families' share to promote the Buddha's ancestral temple. Respectfully serving the wise assembly and providing them with clothing and food, I compassionately care for the flying insects, wriggling creatures, and crawling beings;
If one does not add to the misfortune of those whose minds are already uneasy, the merit of this will follow me wherever I go, like a shadow following a form. This is what is meant by private wealth.
As for the five family divisions:
One is water, two is fire, three is thieves, four is officials, and five is the end of life.

The body and family treasures are abandoned in the world, and one must depart alone. The doors of misfortune and blessings are not known where they will lead. Seeing the world as an illusion, I dare not have them.
Considering the five family divisions, there may be ten billion. This is the den of misfortune, always fearing it will endanger me. How dare I have them?
I wish the multitude of gentlemen would carry them away, to remove my worries.
The king said:
Indeed, these are true words.
He then sent them away.
He withdrew to the meditation room, calmed his mind and contemplated intently, and then awakened, saying:
The body is not even guaranteed, how much less the country, wife, children, and multitude of things, that can be obtained for a long time?

He then compiled and recorded the Buddha's scriptures, reciting the texts and explaining the meanings. His mental defilements were illuminated and removed. He advanced, accepted sincere advice, granted a general amnesty to the country, returned the people's treasures, and discussed leniency and correctness with the officials.
He said to the officials:
Those who have not seen the wonderful meaning and heavy precepts of the Buddha's scriptures are deaf and blind!
The householders are rich, but I am poor!

He then ordered the country to distribute wealth and treasures, providing for the poor and needy according to the people's desires. He established Buddha temples and suspended silk and burned incense, providing meals for the Å›ramaá¹‡as, and personally observed the six precepts.
In this way, for three years, the four borders were peaceful and bandits completely ceased. The five grains ripened, and the people had no hunger or cold.
After the king's life ended, he was immediately reborn in the second heaven.
The Buddha told the monks:
The king at that time was me.
The householder was ÅšÄriputra.
The one who advised the king to observe the country was Ä€nanda.
The bodhisattva's practice of giving with compassion and wisdom is like this.
[The Story of the Householder Xian Tan] (8) In the past, the Bodhisattva was a great householder named Xian Tan, whose wealth was innumerable.

Seeing the Buddha's teachings, he realized that the world is impermanent, that glory and life are difficult to preserve, and that wealth does not belong to oneself. Only the merit of giving is imperishable.
He ordered the people:
'If there are any poor and destitute, take what you wish.'
In this way, for several months.
At that time, the government was lenient and the people were wealthy, with no one lacking in finances.
Xian Tan thought:
'I should only buy medicine to protect the people from illness.'
He then bought good medicine to save the lives of the people. His compassionate nurturing reached everywhere, and his kindness was all-encompassing.

For many years, his virtue and fragrance spread far and wide. The sick from all directions rushed to him. From head to tail, they praised his great kindness and generosity, equating his virtue with that of Heaven.

I have exhausted all my wealth and am now going to collect treasures. I will leave home and go over a hundred li. On a certain water, I encountered several carriages carrying heavy patients, who said:
'Where are you going?'
I replied:
'I am going to the place of Xian Tan, hoping to save the rest of my life.'
Xian Tan immediately returned and borrowed five hundred taels of gold from the king to buy medicine to treat them, and the patients all recovered.
He himself went with merchants to the sea to collect treasures, and obtained a great deal.
Returning to the country, he put down the boat and walked. On the way, there was no water. Xian Tan found a well and called people to draw water from it. He then took some himself to drink.
The merchants saw the white pearl he obtained, shining brilliantly, and out of greed and evil, they slandered the sage and harmed the benevolent, and together they pushed Xian Tan into the well.
The Bodhisattva's benevolent virtue moved the gods and spirits. The celestial gods received him and prevented him from being injured.
The merchants returned to the country, and the king said:
'Where is Xian Tan?'
He replied:
Since leaving the country, I don't know where I am.
He said:
So you killed him?ğŸ”½He replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
The sage sighed, saw an empty hole beside the well, followed it and came out of the well of that house. After seven days of travel, he reached his original country.
The king said:
Why did you return empty-handed?
He replied:
I did not find him.
The king thought quietly:
There must be a reason!
He summoned the merchants and asked:
If you truthfully confess, you will be released. If you deceive, you will die.
They all confessed and were handed over to prison to be sentenced.
The sage wept and ran to the palace gate, knocking his head and begging for forgiveness.
The king said:
You violated the law.
He earnestly requested again:
The foolish see wrongly, which is not enough to be blamed.
Forgive their ignorance.
